event.title: 1692 during King William's War, the village was burned

data.event: In 1692 during King William's War, the village was burned, so the Canibas tribe abandoned the area.
The French and Indian Wars finally ended in 1763, leaving the region open for English colonization.
Fairfield Plantation, named for its fair aspect, was first settled in 1774.
Benedict Arnold and his troops rested and re-provisioned here in 1775 during their march up the Kennebec River to the Battle of Quebec.
On June 18, 1788, it was incorporated as Fairfield.
In 1837, it produced 11,531 bushels of wheat and a large quantity of wool.
